messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I don't think we should accept the SAMPA encoding as the default, since
> it forces users to forgo some natural pairs. Specifically, for years all
> of us have typed "y" for the sound in Yes [j], "j" for the sound in
> "judge" [dZ], and "I" for the proper pronoun [aI]. I can't accept giving
> up such an obvious keyboard mapping simply because SAMPA, a tool for
> linguists, and seemingly based on European languages in general rather
> than English specifically, says so. So I think we should adopt a
> standard for ASCII based on what is easiest for English speakers to use
> and remember. SAMPA is no more a standard for QS than the meter is for
> measuring the volume of water.

Et Peter R. Guinness scripsit:

> The only benefit that sampa does offer is that it is based on a
> linguistic standard and as such it helps people who are already
> familiar with the standard. But as has already been pointed out by
> other group members this benefits only a very, very small precentage
> of the general population. The fact that it doesn't use everyday
> common keys/sound combinations (such as y for 'ye') actually
> disadvantages most people.

Of course I am one of the people who know X-SAMPA backwards and forwards,
so I like QS-SAMPA (and never mind that I invented it). I agree that
while it may work for typing QS in plain ASCII emails, it does not work
very well as a font encoding standard, for the reasons given. I would
rather see a more conservative set of changes to the pre-existing standard
mapping used instead. For example, I think /D/ for They is extremely
clear and intuitive, much more than /H/. A few careful adjustments
would I believe serve the group purposes much better than adhering to a
standard that is intended to be language-neutral. We are typing English,
and we might as well make things easier for TO-using anglophones.

--
Yes, chili in the eye is bad, but so is your John Cowan
ear. However, I would suggest you wash your cowan@...
hands thoroughly before going to the toilet. http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
--gadicath
